Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 10:28AM Annie62 wrote: Sandra's daughter, 1. Your mom should definitely do Herceptin at a minimum. There is a forum for Her2+ women. 2. It's not clear that the surgeon sent the 3 nodes to pathology. Did he and are you waiting on the report? It should take 3 weeks. If they didn't, I agree that is very strange. My surgeon, after getting a positive sentinel node, did an axillary dissection in the same surgery. I also don't do well with anesthesia and pain killers. I threw up for days from percocet. My subsequent surgeries were much easier - shorter time under anesthesia, different pain killers. 3. Get a 2nd opinion for sure. I did even though I was happy with onc.And the surgeon sounds like more of a problem than the onc. The oncs see a lot of patients. Its good that you are watcing out for your mom. 4. If your mom does further surgery (lymph nodes) use a surgeon who specializes in breast surgery if possible. 5. A PET scan will also show axillary lymph nodes that might have cancer so the dissection might not be done. On the other hand, if its only moved to nodes and you can remove it, that's less cancer in your body. 6. The onc may be able to order an oncotype test that will give an idea if chemo will be helpful or not. Good luck to you, Annie 4.

Posts.Title: Your Best Healthy Recipe Let-It-Be jenn3

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2009 07:20AM - edited Dec 14, 2009 11:10AM by Annie62 This dish takes a while but it's really delish, freezes well, and has large portions for the calories.  8 oz ground lean beef or turkey (I use turkey) 1/2 cu chopped onion (I sometimes use frozen chopped to save time) 2 tsp prepared mustard (I use Grey Poupon) 1/8 tsp lemon pepper 2 cups coarsely chopped cabbage (can buy pre chopped in bag) 2/3 cup (2 oz) uncooked white rice (regular, not minute rice) 2 tablespoons Brown Sugar Twin or equivalent brown sugar 28 oz can tomatoes, chopped with juice (small dice works best) Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In large skillet coated with butter flavored cooking spray (I use  olive oil), brown meat (could add a little garlic if desired). Spray an 8 X 8 in baking dish with butter flavored spray (I use olive oil or canola PAM). Layer cabbage in bottom of dish. Cover with onion, browned meat and rice. In small bowl combine chopped tomatoes with juice, mustard, Brown Sugar Twin, and lemon pepper. Pour tomato mixture over rice. Cover and bake 1.5 hours. Uncover and bake 10 more minutes. 4 servings, 193 calories, 5 g fat, 3 g fiber I tried to make this with brown rice but could never get the liquid amount or cooking time down. You could make this veggie by leaving out the turkey. I noted my tweaks on the basic recipe. Also I always use a 1 lb package of turkey and double the recipe and freeze half. We eat half for dinner and bring the leftovers for lunch during the week. Annie

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2014 02:12PM Annie62 wrote: Hi Missy, I traveled to Ireland (Republic) this summer and loved that TripAdvisor was so popular there. It helped me find great restaurants. Lots of NYC restaurants are on Trip Advisor.  Check to see if Restaurant Week is during your stay. You can eat in really nice places for much less during the promotion.  Blue Fin in Times Square is a good recommendation. I've been there for brunch on the weekend and it was reasonable (for NYC)  and very good. Chinatown is a good recommendation for reasonable food. The subway makes it easy to try different neighborhoods in Manhattan so you might be able to find a place cheaper than in midtown. The lower east side has lots of reasonable places in all types of cuisines. If you want to stay in midtown going west (9th /10th Ave) above 40th has lots of places.  Becco is in midtown and has a prix fixe pasta dinner that is a good value. The food is good.  LIttle Korea is about one block in the 30's that has good Korean BBQ places. Lots of fun. You can cook your own food on a table top grill. Oh and during your visit if you get tired of 'foreign' food, Tir Na Nog has two locations - one at 33rd near 8th ave and the other one in Times Square. I met a man in Ireland this summer who said he ate there every night he was in NYC. :) Have a wonderful visit.

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2009 12:05PM Annie62 wrote: I  understand completely how you feel. You would think that the chemo room nurse would be a little more on the ball about how her words would affect you. I think a good rule of thumb would be - don't talk Stage IV to patients who aren't Stage IV unless they ask. This reminded me of one of the worst things someone said to me. I am one of those people that didn't really get bothered by insensitive things people said. There were a couple of comments, all well intentioned, that got to me a bit but I knew that the person who spoke meant well and was someone who didn't have tons of experience talking to a cancer patient. But one comment still makes  me angry. I was in the recovery room after my lumpectomy. I felt horrible. I was puking and was in a lot of pain (I was under for a long time because the sentinel node came back positive and it turns out that I don't do well on percocet). So the the surgeon gives DH and me the bad news about the lymph  nodes and how I'll need to meet with an oncologist now and how I'm not really early stage anymore. I feel so horrible physically and they are trying to get me out of there since I'm not supposed to stay the night and the recovery nurse says to me " Don't worry, if you don't have clear margins or if it comes back you can get a mastectomy and the plastic surgery looks great these days." It hit me like a sucker punch. This was not the moment to be thinking that I needed another surgery! I already felt worse than I'd ever felt in my life from surgery and had just heard for the first time that this wasn't almost Stage 0. Since then I"ve spoken to a number of patients and doctors who agree that while they love the facility and the doctors, the nurses at this hospital leave something to be desired. Try not to let what the nurse said keep you down any longer. Focus on what your onc says and how well you are doing. Oh and don't think that because you don't have a ton of SEs that the chemo isn't working. My SEs weren't that bad either. I don't think there is any correlation between SEs and how well the chemo is working.  I hope to day gets better for you.....  Annie

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2008 08:22AM Annie62 wrote: Re: Erica's recommendation on Cetaphil. The Cetaphil moisturizers that she mentions are paraben-free but the cleanser is not. Just an fyi.  Other lines that have commonly available and not too pricey paraben-free items (make sure you check the ingredients as some individual items may contain parabens), are Alba, Jason (although I'm not crazy about the Jason line), Avalon Organics. Avalon makes nice bath gets etc. I've used Alba lip balms and moisturizers which were pretty nice. I don't like Jason shampoos but the conditioner was ok; I found the vitamin E night cream heavy but use it on my hands or when my 5 yr old gets chapped winter cheeks/hands. Kiss My Face, Tom's of Main and Burts Bees are other options.  I'm think I remember a whole discussion on this - maybe from the alternative forum? Lots of good info online if you google it.  As for myself, I try new items as I find them. Some of my products still have parabens because I haven't found an acceptable substitue yet. Deoderants, lip balm and skin creams which I use frequently and stay on the skin and could potentially be absored. are more important to me to be paraben free. I don't worry so much about shampoo as it is washed out. I wear make-up infrequently so I dont' worry about that either, but if I find a paraben-free item I like I use it. Annie

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 05:32PM Annie62 wrote: Deb, You did not overreact. When I had my first surgery, the nurse had difficulty getting the IV in. She told me they get two tries and if they can't do it (everyone has a bad day), they get another nurse. And that's just what she did. I didn't have to say anything. Also, for chemo I found that most nurses slid the needle right in, no problem. One used to push a bit harder and it was slightly painful and just unsettling. I found myself tensing up before chemo because of this. I mentioned it to my onc and she prescribed me lidocaine cream that I put over the port about an hour before chemo. Couldn't feel a thing. I figure you are going through enough already - every little thing that helps should be done. I'll bet they even have samples they could give you since you use so little and you wouldn't even have to go the drugstore.  It was a generic and the co-pay was small for me. Take care, Annie

We drink soda, not pop here in central NJ/NYC. We eat subs unless we are 'at the shore' and then we eat hoagies. I make spaghetti sauce but lots of traditional American-Italians here make 'gravy'. To me gravy is what you serve with a roast. I also know a lot of people who say 'macaronis' for any pasta and always plural. They are from north NJ. And who carries a purse as opposed to handbag? Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2013 01:41PM Annie62 wrote: Wow, now I'm hungry! A clarification on square pizza in NYC area. A thick square pie/slice is Sicilian and has a softer crust and a thin crispy crust is a 'Grandma slice' or 'Grandma pie'. So yummy. We had cousins from Ireland visit and stay with us one summer. Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2012 01:40PM Annie62 wrote: Wish I didn't have to add to this post but after spending a week in the hospital, I have a few beauts to add. How are healthcare workers so clueless? My favorite. I'm in the emergency room (for hours) with breathing problems related to pleural effusion waiting to be admitted. I'm alone since DH is home with my 9 year old. I'm pretty tough and told him to stay home and just come up in the morning when she goes to school and we had family picking her up after.  My nurse, Richard, I guess in an effort to 'connect' with me felt he had to tell me about how his 54 year old mother left his family too soon after dying of colorectal cancer. Oh yeah, that makes this 49 year old mother of a 9 year old feel really great. Don't they give them training in nursing school that says 'do not tell sick people about people who have died'. It doesn't cheer them up.  Most of the nurses/techs were good with few not so good. I had one nurse who kept talking to me about God even though I told her I was not a believer and she offered to do a massage on my shoulders and she basically just was trying to do this guided imagery thing. Horrible. Thankfully  I only had her for one shift. She also let me know she was skilled in pain management and works for hospice. thanks. I want to think about hospice right this very second. But her best remark was when checking my breathing she asks me if I'm going to do reconstruction. Why are you asking me that? What does it have to do with my care for pleural effusions. Why would I want to discuss it with you instead of a plastic surgeon? It was weird. Just to show I'm not overly sensitive, when i was getting dressed to leave, the nurse assisting me (who just came on shift and was very nice) asked me if I had a bra. I said 'don't need those anymore'. She realized what she did and apologized but I was laughing. that I thought was funny. I think she was relieved.

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2011 06:20AM Annie62 wrote: Creese/Cathy, I saw your comment on wigs and the heat in Texas. On the Chemotherapy forum, there is a pinned topic for 'headcovering during chemo'. One of the companies is FranceLuxe. They have a 'good wishes' program where they will send you a headwrap at no charge. I think these were one of Oprah's 'favorite things'.  I got mine about a week ago. It's a beautiful pattern (you pick) in silk. Unlined so it will be great when it gets warmer here in NJ. I is slightly tight, but I will snip the spandex in the rear a bit. I have a pretty big head. You do order by size. Oh and it is pre-wrapped so you don't need to learn how to do that. My favorite headscarf is the BeauBeau. Lots of choices. Easy to style (leave tails hanging, make a side knot.) It has a cotten lining which prevents slipping and is pre-wrapped. I like the cotton lining. I hope its not too hot on me in summer because its my fave. If yes, I'll see if she makes unlined ones. Sizing was good for me. It cost about $70. I do wear a wig for work, but my othe favorite hat is a thin cotton one from ACS TLC catalog. Its a black beret. Fits well and I add pins to the fron to dress it up. It was reasonably priced. I thing about $16. I got a wiglet thing that I can attach to the edges and just a bit of hair shows. It can be a little itchy but its good for quick stops when I don't want a full wig but don't want stairs. I think it was $25. Something like this might work for you when its hot if you can find a lightweight hat or scarf to connect it to. I hope this helps, Annie

Posts.Title: MBC is Not a "Journey" Bestbird cliff

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2014 02:18AM Annie62 wrote: I think one of the reasons I don't like the word journey is that I feel like my life has become much smaller since my MBC dx.When I think of journey, although there may be low points and a meandering path, there is always the possibility of things getting back on track or even better. That will never be the case for me.  I don't have the energy for all the things  I did before, I need to schedule my life around appointments and how I'll feel after treatment. Making long term plans is difficult (or pointless in the case of very long term plans as I won't be here.) To me it has a context of trying to make others feel better about our sucky situation. Well, I feel like cancer has become my life and how I am defined now. Calling it a journey just amplifies that feeling and gives it even more importance and that what came before is over and not how I am viewed by others anymore.   As to the battle/warrior terminology, I'm not crazy about that either. I don't mind 'fight' so much but I would cringe if someone called me a warrior.  All that being said, I may not use those words, but when other people with cancer or their families do it doesn't bother me. If it works for them that is great. It doesn't affect me. It's like the 'dumb things people have said to you thread'. I've had a few doozies, but most were from a place of people trying to help, so while I may shake my head at those comments, they don't make me mad. Of course comments that are not well intentioned or from medical professionals who should know better are a different story.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2013 10:01AM Annie62 wrote: Liz- I haven't read the other replies but here is my experience: Stage IV is considered a compassionate allowance and you basically get approved automatically. My onc was helpful in filling out the forms for this properly to make sure this was granted. Was on STD through my job for 6 months. The insurance company that my firm uses took care of transitioning me to LTD and outsourced my SSDI applications at no charge as well. So you don't get SSDI untill he STD is done. We started the SSDI application before LTD kicked in and it will take a while for it to be finally approved. They will pay back to the effective date. Because I was a 'high wage earner', the amount I get in SSDI is deducted from my LTD. So the first SSDI payment is deposited into an a account and I won't touch it until the insurance company takes the reimbursement. I chose to go for the SSDI even though I end up with the same total payment because my daughter will also get SSDI and it will be set up when I die and my husband won't have to deal with it. They also help you handle anything that comes up which is helpful. Also, my state, NJ has STD disabiltiy payments. My STD throught he insurance company also deducted that from my STD payment but the handled the whole thing. For people who make less than I did, you may end up with more on STD + state STD and then the LTD + SSDI. Hope this helps. Annie

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2012 08:26AM Annie62 wrote: Hi many, I had terrible pain my neck shoulder and arm (mx side) that lasted months. I had a pinched nerve. Physical therapy and massage helped somewhat. I couldn't sleep and the dr gave me ativan which helped. I also used over the  counter pain meds (tylenol), and muscle rubs like ben gay or aspercreme. This went on for months. Docs did bone scan which showed some arthritis and one suspicious area (in an area of no pain). Ended up going through biopsy. Finally six months later I got the all clear. I use the 2 week rule of thumb. It may get better in the two weeks. if it lingers then your wife may want to get a scan. I suspect that she has a pinched nerve or other muscle pull/sprain not mets. As my doctor says, having had cancer doesn't mean you get a pass on all the other medical problems.  Hang in there, Annie

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2010 03:32PM Annie62 wrote: Hi Kandy, I had an allergic reaction to Taxol. Its not uncommon. The reaction was actually caused by the solution that the taxol is in, not the taxol itself. The solution (not sure if that is technically what it is but I figure you know what I mean), is called Cremaphor. I was able to take Taxotere instead. I understand your feelings about not throwing every available item in the arsenal at the cancer, but try to focus on all the treatments you did have. Did you do AC and rads? Are you on tamoxifen or and AI now?   Best to you, Annie

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 08:49AM Annie62 wrote: TS - they do the snb while you are having surgery so you'll be under and won't feel it. They send it to pathology while they do the mastectomy and if it's positive, they will take  more nodes. If it is negative, no  more nodes taken. In terms of recuperation my axillary disssection didn't hurt anymore than the lumpectomy did (back in 2004).

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 06:40AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:14AM by Annie62 Pink- This is what I know so far of my recurrence. They think it may have been an area of DCIS 6 years ago that wasn't picked up on the same side (left). And now is large enought to be found. It is IDC again. ER/PR+. Her2-.  Not sure on size - I'm hearing about 1 cm at this point. It apparently has not spread to any other organs altho an infraclavicular node did light up on the PET scan.Don't know about chemo yet - probably depends on that lymph node. Have a bilateral for peace of mind. There is also something small on the right that they are pretty sure is benign but they couldn't find with the ultrasound for a biopsy.  So I decided today was my deadline for choosing implants or no recon. Since I had rads on my left side 6 years ago, the PS told me that if I don't do recon now, if I ever do it in the future, implants are not likely to be a choice. The skin will just not handle it  between rads and scarring from the mastectomy. I think I'd be okay with no recon but am afraid I'll regret my decision in a year or two and then I'd have to have a DIEP which is a very long surgery and will cut the abdomen. Not crazy about that. Not crazy about silicon or cutting pec muscle either though! I am so not good with ambivalence! I also did some holiday shopping when I went out for some sweat shirts and pants to wear while recovering. I got a bed wedge to help prop me up in bed - easier to get out and one of those pillows with arms (I think they used to call them bed husbands). I haven't had one since college. I heard it help prevent you from rolling over in the night becasue of the arms. I thought I'd try both and see which works better.  Gigi - Marco island - that sounds lovely! Tammy - I'm so glad you had a good time at the party. When I was originally dx, DD was 20 months old. I was still recovering from a second surgery, working full time and about to start chemo on her 2nd bday. Needless to say, we had some cake and that's it. I'm so glad you were able to celebrate. Be back later, Annie

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 04:31PM Annie62 wrote: Hey Shanagirl, I feel your pain. Intercourse was painful although I didn't have bleeding. I use the vagifem inserts and a lube called 'Pur' - both recommended on the mojo thread. I got 'permission' to use Vagifem a little differently than described and that helped alot. Rx is for daily insert for 2 weeks and then 1 every two weeks. I needed to do about 4 weeks straight then 2 x per week for 1-2 months and now every 2 weeks. I hate the replens but used it at the beginning altho now I don't. It would probably help but i hate the goopieness. The other important change for me was getting the Hitachi magic wand. It works so well it is actually too good  at this point and I'll be 'downsizing' to a pocket rocket. All this said, I don't get in the mood on my own but when DH is in the mood, the things will help me get to a point of either being neutral or actually enjoying it all. It sometiimes is uncomfortable but never excrutiatingly painful the way that it was.  It is a depressing to I know I won't ever be where I was before all of this, but I've gotten to a point where I can enjoy myself a bit , occasionally, and still feel like I'm a good partner to DH.   I hope this helps. Annie

I started crying again. Her teacher must have gone through a box of Kleenex after that project.

The rest is responding to others posts since my last post 1 month ago.  I was in the hospital for a few days (discovered brain mets) for those who don't know. I hope you get relief soon.  Diane - so sorry everyone is so sick. That is awful. I hope you are all on the mend now.  Kjones and Kebab - the Camp Kesem reunion is this weekend. Parents stay.Let you know how it goes. You know I was nervous about sending her in August. some of the kids parents had died. Finding out the liver mets exploded in late August and ending up in in the hospital in Sept with brain mets, I am so thankful she went. She's going to need more support going forward I think. She has been a real trooper during my recent setback. There are episodes where the girl tries to be more girly and make friends with girls. It's actually a pretty good show with good values. They are old and all in repeats. I think my 23 yr old used to watch them when they were new. She's doing better and was recently invited to a youth group thing on Friday nights. She went and had a great time. Made me really happy. Our family guilty pleasure is Chick-Fil-A.  Chicken sandwiches with extra pickles and if we are really decadent a shake. This year she is going as Korra from Legend of Korra. (avatar cartoon on nick). I found a description of a way to make it inexpensively with no sewing (I can't sew!) from a blog. Decided on bilateral a few weeks back and feel that is the right decision. Whittled it down to implants or no recon and have decided on no recon. I'm pretty sure its the right decision for me but not 100% sure yet. Maybe I'll know by tomorrow. Thanks to all of you who post here about your experiences. Its been very helpful to me in assessing my choices. My bmx is 12/2. I'll be back posting here at some point - probably in January when I'm feeling better. I'll probably be spending more time in the surgery section in the next couple of weeks. This is the hardest decision I've ever made. I know everyone says you can choose to recon later but because I've had rads previously the PS said immediate or not if I'm doing implants. Of the flap surgeries, I'd only do a diep and I really don't want a long involved surgery with possibilty of fat necrosis causing alarms and I don't want any other body sections without sensation. Maybe fat grafting will be a possibility someday.  DH said the sweetest thing to me this afternoon after I told him I called the PS office. "You know you aren't like most other people in our image focused culture. That's one reason why I love you. I think you'll be okay with this."   Take care everyone, Annie Stage IV 8/2012 Liver, brain, bone, mets. Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2008 08:11PM - edited Jul 18, 2008 08:13PM by Annie62 Susan - That stinks - like you don't have enough on your plate!  I had an allergic reaction to my 2nd round of dose dense Taxol. I usually sat in a chair in full sight of the nurses station but that section was full that day so I sat on the other end of the room. About 5 min in my face felt hot, my throat started to close up and I felt really weird. I realized what was happening and tried to catch the nurses attention. They were either engaged with someone else or out of my line of sight. I was about to panic, caught the eye of a fellow patient, pointed at my throat and mimiced not being able to breath. She got the nurses attention and within about 10 seconds I had 3 nurses on me administering epinephrine. The whole thing too maybe 25 seconds but felt like minutes. So then my onc comes in and says, we'll put you on taxotere, do you want to get it today and keep close to schedule? I admit I was relieved thinking it was no biggy but she told me months later it was because she wanted as much chemo in me as possible as soon as possible due to my stage! Anyway sorry for the long story. I haven't had the desesitization protocol. but then again I didn't vomit or have diahrea, so my reaction probably wasn't as serious.   With regard to the private room or room full of patients - I was able to choose my hospital and decide between the two types. i chose the public room. I liked the idea of being with other people even though I just read novels during chemo. Given the reaction I had, I think it worked out best for me.  Susan - I wish you all the best and hope that everything goes smoothly with the desensitiation.   Annie DX 11/04 Stage IIIC 11/20 nodes, 6mm, Grade 2, ER+/PR+ Her2-

Posts.Content: May 15, 2014 08:53AM Annie62 wrote: Hi all, I thought I'd post to this thread since I finally got some good news re:my liver mets. I was dx with mets to liver, lungs and bones 20 months ago. I've been on several different chemos which addresses the lung and bone mets pretty well. My liver mets had been slowly growing in size and then really jumped up after trying faslodex. I've been on Doxil for 3 months now and I finally saw shrinkage in the liver lesions! Yeah. I also have normal liver function during this entire time and my onc even allows me to have the occasional glass of wine. Anyway, I thought I would post because I knew how worried I was that the liver mets just didn't seem to be responding to treatement and finally after 18 months I found something that works. Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 09:04AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:15AM by Annie62 Eileen - I was the same way but fortunately DH was the only one privvy to my decisions. I have gotten some extremely strong encouragement from family and docs to do recon, but I feel it is because they think that I am young and will regret this in the end - say 1-2 years out. I finally realized that a large part of me thought I might be making a big mistake. That did it. Carla - I hear ya on the feeling about having to make a quick decision. Everyone says you can do it later if you want and that's true for most. Since I had rads before, implants are out for me unless I do it now and I don't want to do the other more intense surgical procedures. Worst case if I do decide later on recon I could do a DIEP and deal with additional scars. So I really felt I needed to make a quick decision. I was dx 10/4 so this has been dragging. Thinking about PS delayed my surgery 2-3 weeks but that's okay since I feel like I had time to think about things more. Here are some of the things that helped me decide. First I would pick a day or two and imagine myself having chosen one path. I tried to imagine myself living with a really good outcome on implants and waking up and looking at myself in the mirror, walking round, swimming, laying in bed. Then I would imagine the same with no recon and a slightly less than optimal flat appearance. Dealing with foobs, swimming etc. Wearing summer clothes. That visulization really helped a lot. DH noted that I (actually both of us) tend to overemphasize negative risks and underemphasize potential benefits. We are both pretty risk averse. So I tended to think that I'll be the one with complications from implants and the one with giant dog ears after no recon! I tried to be as balanced as possible when thinking about this stuff. We mostly hear the negatives on this board and when we do get people happy, they tend to be more recent. The happy campers aren't posting about their recon 5-10 years after for the most part.  Pros for deciding no implants: no followups to track potential ruptures in implant, avoid capsular contraction (sp?), avoid additional surgeries and anesthesia, avoid cutting pectoral muscle.  No foreign body in my body. Pros for deciding for implants: no dealing with prosthesis, not looking at my body flat and scarred from mx, I think I might feel younger with them, daily reminder of what I have given up to cancer. In the end, I decided that I think about cancer and how it has affected me every day since October 2004 when I was dx the first time. Looking at myself flat wasn't going to change that. As this is a recurrence and I have density in my breasts and there is something small on the other side they can't see and my cancer likes to travel (already in lymph nodes with small cancer),  getting bilateral was an easier decision for me - but still not easy! I wish I didn't have to give up sensation but being able to work out with a prosthesis and not worrying about posture problems if I end up not liking prosthesis on a daily basis AND the peace of mind is worth the trade off. My breast were never the main part of my sex life anyway- especially since the first go around. FWIW, I'm 48, a small b cup and pear shaped too. I was worried about looking totally out of balane top to bottom. Its just another inspiration to lose the last few pounds I've been working on. I think if I was younger and/or single, I would do recon. If I was much older it would have been an easier decision to say no. But that's for me of course.  In closing - I think its great we have choices despite having to make them in such stressful circumstances. If all people wanted the same things the world would be a boring place. Just wish my life were a little more boring right now! Annie

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2014 09:36AM Annie62 wrote: Starbrightly, your post brought tears to my eyes. I understand that your daughter is a teen and going through a lot but wow. I think you handled it well. I don't know if I could have been that calm in the moment.  My 11 year old had said things like your 6 year old. I explain that I'll always be on medicine and won't be able to do everything I did before (like skiing) but I can do a lot and that thankfully the medicine is working. I also tell her that I will let her know if things change but that she doesn't need to worry. I don't inform her of every little change in my treatment. For the most part this has worked.  I also wanted to let everyone know how Camp Kesem went for my daughter. Camp Kesem is a sleepaway camp that has chapters across the US and is run by college students. The camp is free and for children and teens who either have or had a parent with cancer. The focus is on giving the kids a fun week away from cancer. My daughter went to camp for a week and loved it. She has been to YMCA sleepaway camps and loved those too but I was worried about this one because of the cancer connection. Once towards the end of the week, there is a one-hour session where the campers can talk about anything they like or not talk at all. My daughter said she cried because some of the kids had lost a parent. She told me she shared how scared she was when I was in the hospital for 10 days with pleural effusions but that "I'm better now".  Despite this she said she wants to go back because the rest of the time was so much fun. They did a lot of group activities including skits, talent shows etc in addition to swimming, wall climbing, archery, arts and crafts and games. It seems to me there was more focus on group activities and working together supplemented by individual challenges than at her YMCA camp which is more about individual accomplishment (say wall climbing) supplemented by group stuff. Both approaches are good for her but she really loved Camp Kesem and even made a new good friend.  She also told me some of the other campers stories and combined with some of the parents I saw, many seemed to have a decent quality of life so its not like every kid there has a parent who has a short time left or has died. I explained to her before she went that there are lots of types of cancer and that some are worse than others and some have more treatments available than others and that I'm doing fine. For my part, I think it's good for her to have a place where she can be open about what's going on at home and know there are others like her. She doesn't know anyone else who has a family member with cancer.  If anyone has questions about Camp Kesem, feel free to PM me.

Posts.Content: Annie62 wrote: Wanted to give you all an update. A stinky one unfortunately. I started a new chemo 2 wks ago after a significant progression in my liver. (altho liver function is still pretty normal). Spent the week feeling awful with impossible constipation. (sorry for the tmi). Last Tuesday night while watching tv with my family I felt my right side go numb. Totally scary. Ambulance comes, no stroke or heart attack but they think perhaps a reaction to new meds. I insisted on being taken to the emergency room. The pains in my right side prompted a CT scan and I found out I have brain mets. Small diffuse ones with one or two slightly larger. Swelling around the lesions was causing the tremors/pins/needles on my right side. You can imagine the shock. At one point I couldn't speak or was speaking poorly but a seizure has pretty much been ruled out thankfully.  My poor 11 yr old and DH were pretty freaked. DH has pretty much fallen apart. Spent 3 days in the hospital, have started whole brain rads which the docs seem pretty optimistic about. They think my mets are small enough to go away. I'm praying they are right. Off chemo until rads are done. I can't drive and I'm pretty tired. Not driving is really annoying and scheduling rides to the hospital and organizing our life has been a real pain. Last week I was totally out of it but doing a bit better this week. Needless to say I've sliced a few years off my life expectancy this week. I just hope I'm around for a couple of more years at least. I hope I can get back to my 'normal' in a month or so. If not, I really can't imagine how I'm going to move forward.  I'll be around more but typing is actually kind of hard so I'll check in on you guys when I can. And I'll drop by the brain mets thread too.  Stage IV 8/2012 Liver, brain, bone, mets. Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2010 07:46PM Annie62 wrote: Duh so I realized I hadn't posted the latest on my pathology. So last time I was Grade 2; looks like I'm a Grade 3 this time. Docs were surprised by the extent of cancer in my 'bad' breast. They've been watching this sucker for 6 yrs; I've had mri's, cts, pets; This time they found 1 tumor of 1 cm. The breast also had lots of other multifocal cancer in fields of dcis. all over. I did get good margins (6 mm to the chest wall and 1.2 cm to the skin). The right breast (prophy) had no cancer but did have small benign fibroadenomas (sp?).The couldn't find any nodes to test on the bad side and the ones that came out on the right were clean. Looks like I'll need rads on the one intraclavicular node that lit up on the PET but they couldn't get to and  I suspect they'll want me to have chemo. Again. It sucks. I find out for sure on Wednesday when I meet with my onc.  Its nerve wracking to know that there was lots of cancer that wasn't picked up on mammo, ultrasound, mri, ct, pet because they tell me the cancer hasn't spread to other organs. Well maybe it has and these tests aren't picking it up. I had faith the last time that chemo got it since I was 6 yrs out. Just feeling worried tonight.

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2010 07:58AM Annie62 wrote: Tammy, I hat ACT 6 years ago. Cutting your hair into a bob is a good idea. I got a pixie and when it started to fall out, my husband shaved it. (He shaves his own head). I wish I had gone to a professional for the shave - it would have been a closer shave. I always had a bit of stubble right above my neck in the back.  I had great anti-naseau drugs (kytril and emend). Two days after chemo my stomach was 'off' but never enough to get sick. I stuck to water and toast those days. I had one taxol treatment and had an allergic response at the 2nd so I was switched to taxotere. They are similar but I understand taxol is a little easier to handle re: SEs. Muscle/bone pain was bad for 1 to 1.5 days each treatment. I stayed on the couch. Otherwise okay. I had no stomach sensitivity on that. My brows stayed in until taxotere was almost finished and that helped appearance wise. Dusting a little eyeshadow the color of your hair onto your brows helps give a frame to the face and is more subtle than an eyebrow pencil. My hair was already started to come back while on Taxotere.  Overall the fatigue of chemo is cumulative. I was beat by the end and did throw up once. I was feeling okay and commuted to the office (about 1.5 hrs on public transportation) and got sick when I arrived. Turned around and went home by car service. So try to take it easier as it progresses. I highly recommend the port. Why don't they want to give you one? I had one and will be getting one this time around as well. It was a very short procedure that you stay away for (but sedated).  I have a wig. I went for similar color but long and wavy and sexy! I need to dig it out. I may restyle into a shorter style to keep things simple this time around. I had days I couldn't keep it on my head because it bothered me but it worked when I had meetings or when I went to a big bash during treatment. I couldn't keep scarves on my head - they slipped off. I wore some hats but I have a big head LOL and it was hard to find comfortable ones that fit. I'm not a fan of baseball caps. I wore a velvet turban at home in winter when it was cold (and used to walk around saying 'I'm ready for my close up Mr. DeMille), a nice handknit watch cap hat at the office and just went bald in summer. My office is casual and I could get away with that.   Best to everyone. Zogo hope you get some satisfaction with the skin graft area. I'm thinkingof you. Annie

Posts.Content: May 9, 2014 08:50AM Annie62 wrote: LNM - I agree with the others. I think a second opinion at a large cancer center is in order. It may result in a confirmation of your doctors treatment plan. My onc wouldn't even care about the lymph nodes unless they were the only mets I had.  I think what they are saying about the bone mets is that you could be seeing healing not worsening. As long as I didn't have pain and my blood counts were good and/or there wasn't an obvious large scale worsening of the bone mets, my onc wouldn't pay much attention to that and would focus on the liver/lung mets.   Questions I would ask the doctor:  -After the next scan if a similar level of progression was seen would he change treatment? If yes, then he is toeing the line because he thinks this was always there and just not seen on the prior scan. -Ask what treatment  options he's considering if after the next scan there is progression. That way you can do some research ahead of time.  - In your liver and lungs, is this considered a low volume of disease. 8mm is pretty small but it depends on how many there are.  Good luck. You'll need to gather all your records for the second opinion which can be a pain but I found mine gave me peace of mind that my treatment plan was a good one. Annie

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 01:41PM Annie62 wrote: Hi Mary, Been on Gemzar as a single agent for about 6 months. Just added Faslodex to the mix. I get infusions in 3 week cycles. Two on, one off. It is an easy chemo as far as I'm concerned. No hair loss, no appetitie issues (I even had them stop the anti-naseau meds which constipated me). My white counts are sometimes a little low at the second week and I've had neulasta shots once or twice. Some fatigue and when I climb a lot of stairs I can feel it. If I was working the fatigue might be much more of an issue. I had initally very good results - bone mets appear stable, lung under control and liver seemed stable. Last scan saw mixed response in liver - some smaller, some bigger, and a new lesion. Onc keeping me on since bones/lungs doing well and I'm tolerating this very well. That's why we added faslodex. I hope this works for you and that you find it do-able SE-wise. In terms of future chemos, I see you haven't done Halaven. Is that an option for you? I don't believe it is in pill form.

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2008 02:24PM Annie62 wrote: Lynette, It is unlikely to have metastisized. However, I had a 6 mm IDC Grade 2. Ended up with 11/20 lymph nodes positive so I was stage IIIC despite the small tumor. Had full body CT scans and it had not spread anywhere else. Had lumpectomy, re-excision, chemo, rads, tamoxifen and now on aromasin. I am almost 4 years out and doing great. The onc thinks the reason it spread is because of the location - near a vascular area - so I guess it was easier for it to travel. Thankfully my lymph nodes did their job. I found out later that the radiologist at the hospital used my records as a case study in  a lecture because they were so surprised that such a small tumor had spread, so it is unusual.  I wish you the best possible report. Annie

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 05:25AM Annie62 wrote: Morning all, I'm finally getting around to posting. Surgery was on Monday, released on Tuesday around noon. I'm doing very very well. I can't believe how well. I haven't had to take 1 painkiller since my bmx with no recon. I threw up a little after drinking water while still at hospital but nothing since Tuesday. Compared to my lumpectomy/axillary dissection 6 yrs ago this is a cake walk! Last time lots of pain and was vomiting for days. I guess it was mostly due to the  anesthesia and pain meds. I told them this time how I reacted. They gave me a motion sickness patch in pre-op and I think that really helped. I did take vicodin at bedtime, not so much for pain but to make me drowsy to help me fall asleep.Believe it or not, I've actually been on work email since Wednesday! Worst problem so far is that I'm itchy. I get a little dizzy occasionally. Will wash up a bit today (sponge bath only) and I'm looking forward to that. Best to everyone else in the group. I hope your recovery goes as well as mine is so far.  Annie

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 06:39PM Annie62 wrote: Hi all, Regarding Lands End for mastectomy suits. I got on their site early to have a selection (last year they had none left in my size at all). I read the reviews and there were many that were unhappy saying that the pockets have an opening at the top which means you can see the form. I can't even imagine that. Anyway I didn't order one and I'm doing a search online for a suit. Another option is to have pockets sewn into a regular suit. Nordstroms will do it. if you don't buy the suit from them they charge $12 which is very reasonable. TLC sells the 'pockets' if you can sew or you could bring them to a tailor.  Annie

Posts.Content: Annie62 wrote: Hi all- I love to read about 'long-term' survivors so here's my story. This week is my 5 year anniversary of being diagnosed. I'm doing well health-wise and have been getting back into shape the last year or so. The only continuing negative side effect is that chemopause killed my libido and made physical relations with DH uncomfortable. I am working on that and have seen some slight improvement. Thanks to the mojo thread for its suggestions.  I still think about cancer almost every day. I rarely post because I'm trying to stop thinking about it everyday. I look at my almost 7 year old and realize I hardly remember the year she was two when I was undergoing treatment. I don't want it to take away any more of my mental energy than necessary.  My bc WAS discovered on a mammogram -my second one. I had a baseline 2 years prior and then missed a year when pregnant. I had 6 micro-calcifications and all the professionals involved in my case were amazed that the radiologist found them. I had the option of wait and see or biopsy  - I was borderline re: the # of calcifications. I wanted them out and thank goodness I did. The cancer was small but had spread to 11/19 lymph nodes.   Since then I had a lumpectomy with re-excision for clean margins, axillary dissection, chemo (TAC), rads, tamoxifen for 3 years, on aromasin now. I had a clear surgical biopsy the year after my treatment (more calcifications) which were likely caused by the initial surgery. My breast is pretty mishapen. Last year I had to have D&C for uterine build-up from tamoxifen. The biopsy cam back negative. So I'm doing well with almost annual reasons to worry. :)  I wish you all the best and look forward to reading your '5 (or more!) year out' posts in the future. :) Best, Annie Stage IV 8/2012 Liver, brain, bone, mets. Halaven Past chemos:Carboplatin/VP16, Xgeva, Doxil, Gemzar, Navelbine, Xeloda, Faslodex Orig Dx 11/2004 St. IIIc IDC 11/19 nodes AC,Taxotere. Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 10:37AM Annie62 wrote: Tundra, Given that you had an allergic reaction to the taxol, you might want to check with onc. (Looking back I should have.) First time around I was doing dose dense Taxol but had a bad allergic reaction at the beginning of the second infusion which they immediately stopped and gave me an epi-pen shot. So I did taxotere and had no allergy issues. The rash this time was after second infusion and a neulasta shot. It wasn't bad and never continued to worsen. Yesterday it really started to clear up. I'll mention it prior to my infusuion this coming Wed. You mentioned low counts - are they giving you neulasta or neupogen to bring up your WBC? Best, Annie

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 10:12AM Annie62 wrote: You may want to vist an orthopedist or podiatrist. I was in pain every morning when I work up - my feet were killing me and my calves ached. WAlking helped a little. Turns out I had plantar fascitis. Got treatment and then orthotics and have no problems now. So it may be that your leg paiin has nothing to do with cancer.  Have they checked you for PAD? (Peripheral artery disease)? If you've been in pain for 2 years you need to get this addressed. Ask your regular doctor to check you out.  I wish you the best, Annie
